item.title: Fuel Tank Quantity Indication Systems (Flight Deck) – Main Tank Indicators

remarks.para: Except for ER operations, one may be inoperative provided:

numlitem.para: Fuel quantity in associated tank is verified by an alternate procedure,
For non-PIP and non-Pegasus FMCs, both EICAS computers are operative,
Fuel flow indications are operative,
FMC FUEL is initialized with known total fuel quantity,
Procedures to identify and contain an inflight engine fuel leak are used,
All main tank boost pumps are operative,
Fuel pump low PRESS lights for associated tank are operative, and
For Pegasus FMCs with Operational Program Software part number 3418-HNP-02C-08 or earlier, Thrust Management System is operative.

note.para: FUEL CONFIG advisory message for lateral imbalance may be inhibited.

operation.para: Review Inflight Engine Fuel Leak procedures in the QRH and the Non-normal section of the AOM.

numlitem.para: Operate the flight with the fuel crossfeed valve(s) closed.

note.para: FUEL CONFIG advisory message or light will not display for a fuel imbalance condition when left or right fuel quantity indicator is inoperative.

numlitem.para: Compare FMC calculated fuel and the operative gauge (times 2) with the flight plan fuel remaining at each waypoint or fix for which predicted fuel is available. The first non-visual clue that a significant fuel leak has occurred will be either:
Excessive engine fuel flow or rapidly reducing fuel quantity indication (if the leak resides on the side associated with an operating fuel quantity indication),
An excessive lateral trim requirement, or
An engine flame-out.

Remain alert for any such indication and at the first detection of an engine fuel leak the crew must shut down the affected engine (flight conditions permitting) to stop the leak and retain fuel. After shut down the fuel remaining in any tank may be used for the operating engine.

Prior to each engine start, confirm that on the FMC Performance Initialization Page FUEL is initialized with the known total fuel quantity. If boxes appear, or the displayed quantity is incorrect, the quantity must be entered manually.

note.para: If fuel quantity is entered manually, MANUAL appears following the entry. The TOTALIZER display on PROGRESS page 2 is blanked and fuel quantity from the Fuel Quantity Processor Unit is ignored for the remainder of the flight. The FMC now uses calculated fuel quantity.

numlitem.para: Prior to each engine start, confirm that fuel flow system inputs are valid on the FMC SENSOR STATUS Page 1 (LEFT AND RIGHT FUEL FLO).
Select maintenance prompt on INIT/REF Page.
Select sensors prompt.
Verify left and right fuel flow inputs are okay.
Aileron trim indication on the control wheel can be used to determine if a fuel imbalance condition exists.
(Optional) Prior to each engine shut down, record FMC CALCULATED FUEL QTY. For flights not requiring additional fuel, this value may be used as a means of determining total fuel quantity.
In case of en route failure of the FMC calculated total fuel quantity, flight crew should keep a fuel log for the remainder of the flight.

note.para: The PROGRESS page 1 display of FUEL quantity and ATA at the last waypoint prior to failure may be used as starting point. In some failure modes, PROGRESS page 2 FUEL USED data may be available.

placard.para: Placard affected Fuel Quantity Indication "INOP" and enter item in Aircraft Deferred Item Log.

maintenance.title: Fuel Tank Quantity Indication Systems (Flight Deck)

note.para: The repetitive inspection required when this item is inoperative must be documented in the Aircraft Logbook at the prescribed intervals. (Refer to GMM, Chapter 3, Section 6.)

maintenance.para: Determine the fuel quantity by one of the following means:

numlitem.para: Check the applicable tank fuel quantity indicator on the fueling control panel (P28). If it is operating normally, it may be used as the means of determining the quantity in the tank with the inoperative gauge. If it is not operating, placard it inoperative and notify the fuel crew that the automatic fueling shutoff function may be inoperative.
Measuring Stick Method
Determine fuel quantity by referring to UPS Fueling Manual B757 section.

Level aircraft laterally and determine the fuel quantity in the affected tank by comparing corresponding Fuel Measuring Sticks. This can be accomplished by comparing fuel stick readings while tanks are being fueled. When main tank with operative gauge has been fueled to the desired fuel quantity, stop fueling of the affected tank. Adjust fuel load until fuel stick readings between tanks agree.
Service the affected tank using one of the following procedures:
Use tank-to-tank transfer as follows:

caution.para: OBSERVE FUEL QUANTITY LIMITS FOR EACH TANK WHEN TRANSFERRING FUEL FROM ONE TANK TO THE OTHER.

numlitem.para: Determine that the tank or tanks to which the fuel is to be transferred (tank(s) with operative quantity gauge(s)) have sufficient capacity to receive the fuel from the tank with the inoperative gauge.
Open the defueling valve.
Open the fueling valve for tank(s) to receive the fuel.
Turn on boost pump(s) in tank being defueled (tank with inoperative quantity gauge).

After the tank is emptied, re-transfer into it the desired quantity of fuel (using the operative gauge of the supplying tank for measuring), or pump in a known quantity from the refueling truck using the truck meter.
Fuel the remaining tanks to the desired quantity in the normal manner.
Empty, then refill the tank with a known quantity of fuel, using fuel truck meter or from another tank with an operative fuel quantity indicator.

For a flight not requiring additional fuel, the FMC CALCULATED fuel quantity recorded at the end of the previous flight may be used to determine total fuel quantity. The fuel quantity in the affected tank may then be determined by subtracting the fuel in the tank(s) with normally operating gauge(s) from the FMC CALCULATED fuel quantity recorded.

note.para: With a fuel tank quantity gauge inoperative, the total fuel quantity indication (MEL 28-41-7-1 and 28-41-7-2) may be in error.
